questions.text: A child with known case of bronchial asthma comes with respiratory distress with respiratory rate 48/min, cannot speak two words, occasional wheeze and oxygen saturation is 95%. You have given 3 doses of salbutamol by nebulization and patient get stabilised and now able to speak a sentence but oxygen saturation falls to 85% . What can be the most probable reason for fall in saturation?

A 60 yr old male, K/C/O DM-II, HTN, dyslipidemia with BPH, taking metformin 500mg twice daily, enalapril 5mg once daily, rosuvas 5 mg once daily and tamsulosin 0.4 mg HS. He underwent cataract surgery and had significant intraoperative events with loosely hanging & billowing of the iris and progressive intraoperative constriction of the pupil despite mydriatic eye drops was being added to maintain dilatation & ultimately prolapse of the iris occurs through the surgical wound, which eventually led to endophthalmitis. He also gave history of recent addition of glimepride 2mg to his ongoing medical treatment due to uncontrolled sugar level. Which of the drug is most likely responsible for above complication?

An old patient suffering from dementia , diagnosed to have Alzhimer’s disease. As a part of his medical treatment . tablet donepezil 10 mg daily is started but patient can’t tolerate it due to repeated diarrhoea. Which of the following can be used as alternative of donepezil by different route to avoid GIT side effects

A 60 yr old patient with history of MI on irregular treatment, comes with a history of dyspnoea on exertion, occasional PND and edema. On examination, BP is 130/80, Mitral regurgitation is present, X Ray shows cardiomegaly, Echo has EF 35% and Serum Creatinine is 1.3. All of the following are true for treatment of this patient except?

options.label: B
options.text: Furosemide will relieve the symptom but no effect on overall mortality

options.label: C
options.text: Digoxin is useful if atrial arrhythmias are present

questions.text: A 26 year old male presented to you with irregular pulse rate, diziness, history of syncope in recent past. On proper diagnosis he is found to be suffering from atrial flutter and immediately started with antiarrythmic treatment. After few weeks of therapy patient again comes to emergency department in unconsious state with BP 90/60. Resident doctor has taken ECG and found changes given below Which drug is responsible for above changes?

A 28 yr old female, known case of myoclonic epilepsy, taking sodium valproate since 2years and her epilepsy is well controlled. Now patient has become pregnant and comes to you for advise as she has come to know that valproate is a strongly associated with teratogenesis. What will be best advice for her antiepileptic treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Stop sodium valproate and start lamotrigine as it is more safe in pregnancy

options.label: C
options.text: Add lamotrigine to sodium valproate for better control of seizure as pregnancy lead to more incidence of seizures

options.label: D
options.text: Continue with sodium valproate and add folic acid to prevent neural tube defects

questions.correct_answer: D. Continue with sodium valproate and add folic acid to prevent neural tube defects

questions.text: A psychotic patient, has been started on tablet haloperidol 5 days back, presented with rolling up of eye balls(oculogyric crisis) and abnormal spasm of lower limb. Which side effect is most likely caused by above drug?

A 26-yrs-old woman with reactive depression complains of missing her period and having milk discharge from her breasts. Pregnancy tests are negative. Which of the following is most likely to have caused these findings?

22 year old pregnant female presented with complaints of Nervousness, Anxiety, Increased perspiration, Heat intolerance, Hyperactivity, Palpitations. Her TSH level was found to be 0.05microIU/L(normal: 0.4-4 mIU/L). She was started with oral drug treatment for above problem but when she delivered, the baby is born with deformity shown in the picture below Which of the following drug is responsible for the above outcome?

A child has come to you with multiple different types of seizures, particularly tonic and atonic seizures. Intellectual development of this child is impaired. The EEG shows a classic pattern of background slowing and spike-wave bursts at frequencies less than 2.5 per second. Which drug shouldn’t be a part of the treatment for the above disease?
A patient, known case of open angle glaucoma, using some anti glaucoma drug since 1year. Now patient has visited to your clinic with problems shown in image. Which drug is responsible for this?

A patient, who was suffering from WPW syndrome, started taking a drug and now come to you with hyper pigmentation of skin and slit lamp examination finding in eyes is given below . Which of the following drug is responsible for these changes ?

A schizophrenic patient comes to OPD with relapse of symptoms due to non compliance with oral drugs he had been taking. He was then prescribed to take depot injection of an antipsychotic drugs. Within two days of depot injection, he developed confusion, disorientation, anxiety, dizziness, excessive sedation, and extrapyramidal symptoms. Which of the following long acting depot injectable responsible for above complication ?

A 44-year-old unemployed nurse with bipolar disorder history since her teens, admitted to the Emergency Departmnt due to high fever (>38°C), severe nonproductive cough, skin rashes, facial swelling, especially around the nose, and erythema on the hands. Her laboratory abnormalities were as follows: leukocytosis (>11x 10 9/L), eosinophilia (>1.5x 10 9/L), atypical lymphocytes (>5%) and liver abnormalities (ALT>100 IU/L). The patient was on multiple mood stabilizers since she was discharged from the Psychiatric Hospital two months before, where she was hospitalized under the diagnosis of acute depressive episode. Which of the following drug is responsible for above complication?

A 52 year old male, known case of stage 4 CKD, on hemodialysis, comes to you with severe pain. As a pain management physician, you want to prescribe opioids as the pain is mainly nociceptive in origin. Which of the following drug shouldn’t be the part of regime which you want to prescribe to this patient?
A patient taking a diuretic for several months presents with significantly elevated serum glucose levels. You suspect it is diuretic induced. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

A patient has very high serum uric acid levels and is at imminent risk of developing acute nephropathy. Which of the following might be used to reduce the risk of this serious response by increasing the solubility of uric acid in the urine?

A patient of essential HTN is treated with usually effective doses of an ACE Inhibitor. After a suitable period of time, BP has not been lowered satisfactorily. A thiazide is added to the regimen . Which of the following is most likely and earliest untoward outcome of this drug add on, for which you should monitor closely?

options.label: A
options.text: Fall of blood pressure sufficient to cause syncope

options.label: B
options.text: Onset of acute heart failure from depression of ventricular contractility

options.label: D
options.text: Sudden prolongation of the P-R interval and increasing degrees of the heart block

questions.correct_answer: A. Fall of blood pressure sufficient to cause syncope

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is admitted with a history of heart failure and an acute left ventricular myocardial infarction. He has severe pulmonary edema. Which of the following drugs is LEAST likely to prove useful in the treatment of acute pulmonary edema?
A 50-year-old man has a history of frequent episodes of renal colic with high-calcium renal stones. The most useful agent in the treatment of recurrent calcium stones is

A patient with long-standing diabetic renal disease and hyperkalemia and recent-onset congestive heart failure requires a diuretic. Which of the following agents would be LEAST harmful in a patient with severe hyperkalemia?

A 70-year-old woman is admitted to the emergency room because of a "fainting spell" at home. She appears to have suffered no trauma from her fall, but her blood pressure is 110/60 when lying down and 60/40 when she sits up. Neurologic examination and an ECG are within normal limits when she is lying down. Questioning reveals that she has recently started taking diuretics for a heart condition. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of her fainting spell?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (B) Amiloride Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) in the collecting duct. It has mild diuretic effects and is not typically associated with significant volume depletion or orthostatic hypotension, making it an unlikely cause of the patient’s fainting.
  • • (D) Hydrochlorothiazide Hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ) is a thiazide diuretic that acts on the distal convoluted tubule, causing moderate natriuresis. While it can cause hypotension, it is less potent than furosemide in causing volume depletion. Additionally, thiazides cause more gradual sodium loss rather than the rapid volume depletion seen with loop diuretics like furosemide, making it a less likely cause of the patient’s acute symptoms.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with severe post-hepatitis cirrhosis is started on a diuretic for another condition. Two days later he is found in a coma. The drug most likely to cause coma in a patient with cirrhosis is
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (C) Furosemide Furosemide is a loop diuretic that causes potent natriuresis by inhibiting the Na + /K + /2Cl - transporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. While furosemide can cause electrolyte imbalances, volume depletion, and worsen hepatorenal syndrome, it does not directly precipitate metabolic acidosis, making it less likely to cause coma in a cirrhotic patient.
  • • (D) Hydrochlorothiazide Hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ) is a thiazide diuretic that works on the distal convoluted tubule, leading to moderate sodium excretion. It does not significantly alter acid-base balance, and while it can cause hypokalemia and hyponatremia, it is less likely to trigger hepatic coma than acetazolamide.

questions.text: A patient who has been taking an oral antihypertensive drug for about a year develops a positive Coomb’s test. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (B) Clonidine Clonidine is another centrally acting β 1 -agonist, like methyldopa, but it does not cause hemolytic anemia. Instead, it can cause rebound hypertension if suddenly discontinued, along with sedation, dry mouth, and bradycardia.
  • • (C) Labetalol Labetalol is a nonselective β-blocker and α 3 -blocker used for hypertension, including hypertensive emergencies and pregnancy-related hypertension. While it can cause hypotension, dizziness, and bradycardia, it is not associated with autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with essential hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and chronic-stable angina develops severe constipation. It is attributed to one of her medications. Which was the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (B) Captopril Captopril is an ACE inhibitor commonly used for hypertension and heart failure. Its adverse effects include cough (due to bradykinin accumulation), angioedema, hyperkalemia, and hypotension, but it does not cause constipation.
  • • (C) Labetalol Labetalol is a nonselective β-blocker and α 1 -blocker used for hypertension, including hypertensive emergencies and pregnancy-induced hypertension. Its side effects include bradycardia, dizziness, fatigue, and orthostatic hypotension, but it is not a significant cause of constipation.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the emergency department in coma with cyanosis. Her mother states that the girl was given codeine with paracetamol because of severe bruising after a fall. Shortly after the first dose, the child became unresponsive and “turned blue.” Which of the following alleles might be responsible for this presentation?

A hypertensive patient has been on long-term therapy with lisinopril. The drug isn’t controlling pressure as well as wanted, so the physician decides to add triamterene as the second drug. What is the most likely outcome of adding this diuretic to the ACE inhibitor regimen?

options.label: B
options.text: Better BP control, but with a risk of hyperkalemia

options.label: C
options.text: Cardiac depression, because both drugs directly depress the heart

options.label: D
options.text: Cough that may be severe, even though there was no cough with lisinopril alone

questions.correct_answer: B. Better BP control, but with a risk of hyperkalemia

questions.text: A friend has very severe hypertension and asks about a drug her doctor wishes to prescribe. Her physician has explained that this drug is associated with tachycardia and fluid retention (which may be marked) and increased hair growth. Which of the following is most likely to produce the effects that your friend has described?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (B) Guanethidine – Incorrect. Guanethidine is a sympatholytic agent that lowers BP by depleting norepinephrine from nerve terminals. While it can cause fluid retention, it typically causes bradycardia (not tachycardia) and has no effect on hair growth.
  • • (D) Prazosin – Incorrect. Prazosin is an α 1 -blocker, which also lowers blood pressure by vasodilation. However, it causes less reflex tachycardia than minoxidil. It does not cause fluid retention as severely as minoxidil, and it does not cause hair growth.

questions.text: A 62 year old female patient who is known case of mild CKD comes to with BP of 160/96. There is no history of Diabetes mellitus and CHF. Which anti hypertensive is the best to start in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (C) Cilnidipine Cilnidipine is a calcium channel blocker (CCB), which works by relaxing vascular smooth muscle to lower blood pressure. While it is effective in treating hypertension, CCBs do not provide the same level of renal protection as ACE inhibitors do. They also do not have the beneficial effects on proteinuria seen with ACE inhibitors. Cilnidipine can be an option if ACE inhibitors are contraindicated, but it is not the first choice in CKD.
  • • (D) Clonidine Clonidine is an α 2 -adrenergic agonist that lowers blood pressure by reducing sympathetic tone. While it can be used in hypertension, it is not a first-line agent for the management of hypertension in CKD. It can cause sedation, dry mouth, and rebound hypertension upon discontinuation. Additionally, it does not provide renal protection and is not recommended for routine use in CKD.

questions.text: A 36-year-old unemployed dishwasher with no history of seizures presents with difficulty thinking coherently and claims he is an astronaut. Following treatment, he suddenly has a grand mal seizure. Which of the following neuroleptic agents was the most likely cause?

A 64-yrs-old woman has had several episodes of transient ischemic attacks (TIAs). Aspirin would be a preferred treatment, but she has a history of severe “aspirin sensitivity” manifests as intense bronchoconstriction. What would be a best suitable alternative to the aspirin?

A patient develops severe thrombocytopenia after 10 days of treatment with unfractionated heparin that is started after a surgery for deep vein thrombosis.. What is best management for the complication developed in above patient

A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 30 min after the onset of right-sided weakness and aphasia (difficulty speaking). Imaging studies ruled out cerebral hemorrhage as the cause of his acute symptoms of stroke. Prompt administration of which of the following drugs is most likely to improve this patient's clinical outcome?

A 2l-year-old man was seen in a clinic with a complaint of dysuria and urethral discharge of yellow pus. Gram stain of the urethral exudate showed gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonucleocytes. The patient informed the clinic staff that he was unemployed and had not eaten a meal for 2 days. The most appropriate treatment of gonorrhea in this patient is

options.label: B
options.text: Ceftriaxone intramuscularly as a single dose

options.label: C
options.text: Procaine penicillin G intramuscularly as a single dose plus 1 g ofprobenecid

questions.correct_answer: B. Ceftriaxone intramuscularly as a single dose

questions.text: A 2l-year-old man was seen in a clinic with a complaint of dysuria and urethral discharge of yellow pus. He had a painless clean-based ulcer on the penis and nontender enlargement of the regional lymph nodes. lmmunofluorescent microscopic examination of fluid expressed from the penile chancre of this patient revealed treponemes. Since he appears to be infected with T pallidum, the best course of action would be to

options.label: A
options.text: Treat with intravenous aqueous penicillin G

options.label: D
options.text: Give a single oral dose of fosfomycin

questions.correct_answer: C. Inject intramuscular benzathine penicillin G

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman recently treated for leukemia is admitted to hospital with malaise, chills, and high fever. Gram stain of blood reveals the presence of gram-negative bacilli. The initial diagnosis is bacteremia, and parenteral antibiotics are indicated. The records of the patient reveal that she had a severe urticarial rash, hypotension, and respiratory difficulty following oral penicillin V about 6 months ago. The most appropriate drug regimen for empiric treatment is

A 2-year-old child is brought to the hospital after ingesting pills accidently that is usually given for dysentery.. The child has been vomiting for over 24 hours, and has had diarrhea with green stools. He is now lethargic with an ashen color. Other signs and symptoms include hypothermia, hypotension, and abdominal distention. The drug most likely to be the cause of this problem is

A 57-year-old man is seen in a hospital emergency room complaining of pain in and behind the right ear. Physical examination shows edema of the external otic canal with purulent exudate and weakness of the muscles on the right side of the face. There are no obvious signs of systemic infection. The patient informs the physician that he is a diabetic, taking glipizide daily but no insulin. He is also taking low dose aspirin daily but no other drugs. Gram stain of the exudate from the ear shows many polymorphonucleocytes and gram-negative rods. Samples of the exudate are sent to the microbiology laboratory for culture and drug susceptibilty testing. A preliminary diagnosis is made of external otitis. At this point, which of the following is most appropriate?

options.label: A
options.text: Analgesics should be prescribed for pain, but antibiotics should be withheld pending the results of cultures

options.label: B
options.text: The patient should be sent home with a prescription for oral cefaclor

options.label: C
options.text: The patient should be hospitalized and treatment started with gentamicin plus ticarcillin

options.label: D
options.text: The patient should be hospitalized and treatment started with intravenous imipenem cilastatin

questions.correct_answer: C. The patient should be hospitalized and treatment started with gentamicin plus ticarcillin

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman has returned from a vacation abroad suffering from traveler's diarrhea and her problem has not responded to antidiarrheal drugs. A pathogenic gram-negative bacillus is suspected. Which one of the following drugs is most likely to be effective in the treatment of this patient?

A 20-year-old woman with leukemia was undergoing chemotherapy with intravenous antineoplastic drugs. During treatment she developed a systemic infection due to an opportunistic pathogen. There was no erythema or edema at the catheter insertion site. A white vaginal discharge was observed. After appropriate specimens were obtained for culture, empiric antibiotic therapy was started with gentamicin, nafcillin, and ticarcillin intravenously. This regimen was maintained for 72 hours, during which time the patient's condition did not improve significantly. Her throat was sore, and white plaques had appeared in her pharynx. On day 4, none of the cultures had shown any bacterial growth, but both the blood and urine cultures grew out Candida albicans. At this point, the best course of action is to

options.label: A
options.text: Continue current antibiotics and start flucytosine

options.label: B
options.text: Stop current antibiotics and start ketoconazole

options.label: C
options.text: Continue current antibiotics and start amphotericin B

options.label: D
options.text: Stop current antibiotics and start amphotericin B

questions.correct_answer: D. Stop current antibiotics and start amphotericin B

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient who is HlV-positive has a CD4 count of 500/gL and a viral RNA load of 5000/mL. His treatment involves a three-drug antiviral regimen consisting of zidovudine, didanosine, and ritonavir. Because of weight loss, he is taking dronabinol. Nystatin had been used for oral candidiasis, but for the past week the patient has been taking ketoconazole. He now complains of anorexia, nausea and vomiting, and abdominal pain. His abdomen is tender in the epigastric area. Laboratory results reveal an amylase activity of 220 units/L, and a preliminary diagnosis is made of acute pancreatitis. If this patient has acute pancreatitis, the drug most likely to be responsible is

A 27-year-old nursing mother is diagnosed as suffering from genital herpes. She has a prior history of this viral infection. Previously she responded to a drug used topically. Apart from her current problem, she is in good health. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be prescribed at this time?

A 27-year-old pregnant patient with a past history of pyelonephritis has developed a severe upper respiratory tract infection that appears to be due to a bacterial pathogen. The woman is hospitalized and an antibacterial agent is to be selected for treatment. Assuming that the physician is concerned about the effects of renal impairment on drug dosage in this patient, which one of the following drugs is LEAST likely to require dosage reduction, even if creatinine clearance is less than 10 mL/min?

A foreigner photographer traveled to Indian jungle region where chloroquine-resistant P falciparum is endemic. She had to stay in India for 4 weeks and took a drug for prophylaxis. The drug she took for prophylaxis was probably

A male patient presents with lower abdominal discomfort, flatulence, and occasional diarrhea. A diagnosis is made of intestinal amebiasis and E histolytica is identified in his diarrheal stools. An oral drug is prescribed and reduces his intestinal symptoms. Later he presents with severe dysentery, right upper quadrant pain, weight loss, fever, and an enlarged liver. Amebic liver abscess is diagnosed and the patient is hospitalized. He has a past history of drug treatment for a tachyarrhythmia but is not taking antiarrhythmic drugs at present. The drug regimen most likely to be effective in treating the hepatic abscess in this patient and in eradicating intestinal infection is

options.label: C
options.text: Emetine plus diloxanide furoate plus chloroquine

questions.correct_answer: D. Metronidazole plus chloroquine plus iodoquinol

questions.text: A sheepherder who lives most of the year in the mountains of Uttarakhand is hospitalized with liver cysts (hydatid disease) attributed to infection with Echinococcus granulosus, the dog tapeworm. He refuses to undergo surgery for removal of the cysts. Which one of the following drugs is most likely to be of some help in this situation?

A 55-year-old woman with insulin-dependent diabetes of 40 years' duration complains of severe bloating and abdominal distress, especially after meals. Evaluation is consistent with diabetic gastroparesis. The drug you would be most likely to recommend is
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Dopamine D 2 receptor antagonism – This enhances gastric motility and promotes gastric emptying by removing dopamine’s inhibitory effect on gastrointestinal smooth muscle. 5-HT 1 receptor agonism – This further enhances peristalsis and improves symptoms of bloating, nausea, and postprandial discomfort. 5-HT 3 receptor antagonism – Provides an additional antiemetic effect, useful for nausea associated with gastroparesis. Since this 55-year-old diabetic woman has had long-standing insulin-dependent diabetes (40 years), her symptoms of severe bloating and abdominal distress after meals strongly suggest diabetic gastroparesis, making metoclopramide the best choice to relieve her symptoms.
  • • Incorrect Answers: A) Docusate: Docusate is a stool softener used to treat constipation by increasing water penetration into stool, making it easier to pass. It has no prokinetic properties and does not help with gastric emptying, making it ineffective for diabetic gastroparesis.
  • • B) Loperamide: Loperamide is an opioid agonist used to treat diarrhea by reducing intestinal motility. In gastroparesis, motility is already impaired, and loperamide would worsen symptoms by further slowing gastric emptying, making it contraindicated in this condition.
  • • D) Sucralfate: Sucralfate is a mucosal protective agent used in peptic ulcer disease (PUD). It forms a protective barrier over ulcers but does not affect gastric motility. Since this patient has gastroparesis, not an ulcer, sucralfate is not an appropriate treatment.

questions.text: A patient is receiving chemotherapy for metastatic carcinoma. She threatens to stop her treatment because of severe nausea and vomiting. Which one of the following drugs is not likely to prevent such chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting is mediated by activation of the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) and vomiting center in the brainstem, which involves serotonin (5-HT 3 ), dopamine (D 2 ), and neurokinin (NK 1 ) receptors. Since levodopa increases dopamine levels, it may even exacerbate nausea and vomiting, making it completely ineffective in this scenario.
  • • Incorrect Answers: A) Dexamethasone:
  • • Glucocorticoids like dexamethasone are commonly used as adjuncts to other antiemetics in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. They reduce inflammation, modulate neurotransmitter activity, and enhance the effectiveness of 5-HT 3 receptor antagonists like ondansetron. Dexamethasone is especially useful in delayed CINV, making it an effective choice. B) Dronabinol:
  • • Dronabinol is a cannabinoid receptor agonist (synthetic THC) that helps reduce nausea and stimulate appetite. It is approved for use in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting when other antiemetics fail. Its central action on the cannabinoid receptors in the vomiting center makes it a viable antiemetic. D) Ondansetron:
  • • Ondansetron is a 5-HT 3 receptor antagonist and one of the most effective antiemetics for CINV. It works by blocking serotonin receptors in the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) and the vagus nerve, preventing both acute nausea and vomiting. It is considered a first-line treatment for CINV.

questions.text: A 50 year old male patient came to psychiatry OPD with hallucination, decreased expressiveness, apathy, flat affect, lack of energy and self injurious behaviour. An antipsychotic drug was being prescribed to control above symptoms. After two weeks of taking treatment, patient presented in hospital emergency with malaise, breathlessness and chest pain. On laboratory examination, it was found that his C-reactive protein level is above 100 mg/L, troponin level is raised to just double of its normal value and eosinophil count is moderately high. Which of the following drug would have been the causative agent for above complication ?

A female patient comes to you with double vision began 6 weeks ago. Her husband reported fluctuating droopy eyelids, in the morning and evening, which started 4 weeks ago. Her plasma laboratory findings have significantly raised anti-Ach receptor antibodies and her EMG has shown decrementing response to 3 Hz repetitive nerve stimulation. She is put on drug therapy and after that her symptoms get relieved. As a precautionary measure which drug should never be given to above patient in future?

A 26 year old non pregnant female known case of primary generalized tonic-clonic seizures since 5 years, well controlled on sodium valproate , wants to conceive and comes to you to take advice for her anti epileptic treatment. Which of the following best advise to her ?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue the same medicine as recurrence rate is high while changing the treatment

options.label: B
options.text: Stop sodium valproate and switch to levitiracetam as it is safe

options.label: C
options.text: Stop sodium valproate gradually and wait for few more months and conceive without taking anti epileptic drug if seizure wont recur

options.label: D
options.text: Its better to postpone the plan to conceive as all anti epileptics have some risk of teratogenesis

questions.correct_answer: C. Stop sodium valproate gradually and wait for few more months and conceive without taking anti epileptic drug if seizure wont recur

questions.text: A 35 year male patient taking sodium valproate for his epileptic disease, now comes to you with severe grade of trigeminal neuralgia and you have decided to add carbamazepine to his treatment schedule. Which of the following side effect incidence can be enhanced due to above drug combination?

A 65 years old male, K/C/O DM-II and CVA and on multiple medicines for same problems, comes to hospital OPD with history of generalised seizure one night before. His renal function was normal. Which of the following should be the best choice to start treatment for this patient?

A patient who is daily wage labour by profession and a known case of epilepsy with DVT since last 10 years, was maintained on tablet phenytoin 300 mg HS, tab warfarin 5mg OD and tab aspirin 75 mg OD. He has now come to you with recurrent episode of seizure. He also gives history of sudden discontinuation of phenytoin and wants to restart it under your guidance. As a treating neurologist, while prescribing phenytoin, all of the following advices can be given except

options.label: A
options.text: Patient should not take drug dose more than 400 mg/day

options.label: B
options.text: He should not frequently switch to other generic phenytoin preparation available in market to make treatment more economical

options.label: C
options.text: He should continue rest of drugs as a part of his DVT treatment

options.label: D
options.text: Cholecalciferol supplementation to be taken on & off during treatment

questions.correct_answer: C. He should continue rest of drugs as a part of his DVT treatment

questions.text: An obese patient comes to you in hospital emergency with status epilepticus and he is stablised by a duty doctor with IV lorazepam 0.4 mg stat and immediately started with IV infusion of broad spectrum antiepileptic . All of the following drugs can be given as IV bolus in above patient except

A 34 years old male suffering from schizophrenia and controlled on tablet haloperidol 5mg/day since last 5 years, now comes to you with repeated protruding of tongue, lips smacking and retraction of the corners of the mouth. There is also history of abnormal chewing movements of face and shoulder shrugging. Except one all of the following drugs can bring relief to above patient if given or added to the treatment

A 70 year old parkinsons disease patient suffering from severe disease, refractory to most of anti parkinsonism drug, has been kept on high dose levodopa therapy to improve quality of life. Now this patient is presented in OPD with delusion of spouse infedility and visual hallucinations. Which of the following antipsychotic is best to start to manage the above complication ?
A 45 year old alcoholic patient with liver cirrhosis has come to you with psychosis, delusion and hallucination. Which antipsychotic out of following is best to start in treatment of above patient?

A 48 year old females comes to neurology OPD with symptoms of hyperreflexia, and spasticity as well as atrophy of muscles and fasciculations. Which of the following drug can slow down the course of above disease ?

A 60 year old patient is diagnosed with Parkinsons disease but having mild symptoms which are minimally affecting his quality of life. Which of the following is the best drug to start treatment in above patient?

A 60 year old female, suffering from advanced stage of multiple myeloma has been kept in hospice centre. In order to improve her quality of life, she has been adviced to take tablet morphine 50 mg three times daily to relieve cancer associated pain. Now she has developed refractory constipation which is not getting relieved with even strong laxatives. All of following drugs can be given for to relieve constipation except:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Naltrexone is not suitable for treating opioid-induced constipation because:
  • • It is a centrally acting opioid antagonist, meaning it blocks opioid effects in both the brain and gut. If given to a patient on chronic morphine therapy, it can precipitate opioid withdrawal and worsen pain control. Unlike Methylnaltrexone, Alvimopan, and Naloxegol, which are peripherally acting, Naltrexone crosses the blood-brain barrier, making it unsuitable for opioid-induced constipation. Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: (A) Methylnaltrexone
  • • A peripherally acting µ-opioid receptor antagonist (PAMORA) that relieves constipation without affecting central opioid analgesia. Approved for opioid-induced constipation (OIC), especially in palliative care patients. Given subcutaneously and works quickly. (B) Alvimopan
  • • Another peripherally acting µ-opioid receptor antagonist used to treat opioid-induced bowel dysfunction. Mostly used in postoperative ileus but can be effective in OIC. Does not cross the blood-brain barrier, so it does not interfere with pain relief. (D) Naloxegol
  • • A PEGylated derivative of naloxone, designed to block opioid receptors in the gut while preserving central analgesia. Given orally, making it convenient for long-term use. Approved for chronic opioid-induced constipation.

questions.text: A female patient was on lithium therapy for bipolar disorder for 6 months.She kept the fast for few days due to religious reasons and presented with seizures, coarse tremors, confusion and weakness of limbs. Which of the following should be done to diagnose her condition?

His ABG shows severe acidosis but blood sugar level is within range. All of the following can be the risk factors for above complications except

He also adds that his symptoms gradually resolves after discontinuation of the same drug but reappear after re challenge. On laboratory examination, anti nuclear antibodies(ANA) and anti histone antibody level comes out to be high. As a treating physician, you would like to rule out all of the following drug as causative agent of above problem except

A 32 year old females, k/c/o depression, comes to you with drug overdosewith marked sedation, confusion and delirium. She has history of seizure at home after drug intake. On examination, you have found she is having ventricular arrhythmias, hypotension, and hyperthermia, flushing and dilated pupils. Which of the following drug has no role in treatment of above patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Key features of TCA overdose in this patient include: CNS depression (marked sedation, confusion, delirium, seizures) Cardiotoxicity (ventricular arrhythmias, hypotension) Autonomic dysfunction (hyperthermia, flushing, dilated pupils) Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist and is used to reverse benzodiazepine overdose. In TCA overdose, flumazenil is contraindicated because it can precipitate seizures, which are already a risk in TCA toxicity. Thus, flumazenil has no role in treating this patient and may worsen the condition.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: (A) Sodium bicarbonate
  • • First-line treatment for TCA overdose. It helps by reducing cardiotoxicity caused by TCA-induced sodium channel blockade, stabilizing cardiac conduction and reducing the risk of arrhythmias. It also alkalinizes the blood, which helps decrease drug toxicity. (B) Phenylephrine
  • • Useful for treating hypotension in TCA overdose. TCAs cause α1-receptor blockade, leading to vasodilation and hypotension. Phenylephrine is a selective α1-agonist that can increase blood pressure without worsening tachycardia, making it a preferred vasopressor. (D) Lidocaine
  • • Used for TCA-induced ventricular arrhythmias. TCAs block cardiac sodium channels, leading to QRS prolongation and ventricular arrhythmias. Lidocaine (a Class IB antiarrhythmic) counteracts this effect and is preferred over other antiarrhythmics like amiodarone.

questions.text: A 52 year old unmarried female suffering from breast cancer and taking adjuvant hormonal therapy tab tamoxifen 20 mg per day as her treatment course. Her mother and two sisters died because of breast cancer and she has also lost all hope to live due to her disease. As a physician you want to improve quality of her life and would like to initiate anti depressant treatment . Which of the following is the best choice for this patient to start treatment with ?

A 3 year old child comes to emergency with vomiting. Nurse posted in emergency gives antiemetic to baby which is generally gives to adult patient. After few hours of hospital stay, child vomiting is stopped but child body gone into spasm with high tone in leg and neck muscles. Which antiemetic that nurse might have given to baby leading to above complication ?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Young children are more susceptible to these effects because their dopaminergic system is still developing, making them more prone to dopamine blockade-related complications. Dystonic reactions occur due to excessive dopamine inhibition in the basal ganglia, leading to abnormal muscle contractions and posturing. Symptoms can be treated with diphenhydramine or benztropine, which are anticholinergic drugs that counteract extrapyramidal symptoms. Due to the high risk of EPS, metoclopramide should be avoided in young children, and safer alternatives like ondansetron (a 5-HT 3 antagonist) should be used instead.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: (A) Aprepitant
  • • Incorrect because aprepitant is a neurokinin-1 (NK-1) receptor antagonist, primarily used for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV). It does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) and is rarely used in pediatric emergency settings. (B) Domperidone
  • • Incorrect because domperidone is a peripheral dopamine D 2 receptor antagonist, meaning it does not cross the blood-brain barrier significantly. Since it has minimal central nervous system (CNS) effects, it is less likely to cause EPS compared to metoclopramide. However, it is not recommended for infants due to cardiac risks (QT prolongation and arrhythmias). (C) Cisapride
  • • Incorrect because cisapride is a serotonin 5-HT 3 receptor agonist, used to enhance gastrointestinal motility. It does not block dopamine receptors, meaning it does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms. However, cisapride is not commonly used due to its association with QT prolongation and cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: A female underwent LSCS surgery and it was performed under spinal anesthesia. As a complication of spinal anaesthesia, she has developed hypotension immediately after surgery. Her BP is 90/70 and HR is 100 per minute. Which is the best vasopressor to be chosen among the following for the treatment of above complication ?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • It is a selective α1-adrenergic agonist, which leads to potent vasoconstriction, thereby increasing systemic vascular resistance (SVR) and blood pressure (BP). It maintains uteroplacental perfusion, making it particularly suitable in obstetric patients undergoing lower-segment cesarean section (LSCS). It does not increase heart rate (HR), which is beneficial in this case as the patient already has a compensatory tachycardia (HR = 100 bpm). For these reasons, phenylephrine is now considered the first-line agent for managing spinal anesthesia-induced hypotension in obstetric settings.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: (A) Ephedrine
  • • Previously used but now less preferred due to its mixed α and β adrenergic agonist effects. Increases HR and cardiac output, which may lead to tachycardia and fetal acidosis. Although effective, phenylephrine is now favored over ephedrine in obstetric patients due to better BP control and fewer side effects on fetal acid-base balance. (C) Methoxamine
  • • Like phenylephrine, it is a pure α 1 agonist, but it has a longer onset of action, making it less useful in an emergency setting. It can also cause excessive reflex bradycardia, which is not ideal in this case. Phenylephrine is preferred because it has a more predictable and rapid effect on BP stabilization. (D) Droxydopa
  • • It is a prodrug of norepinephrine, primarily used for neurogenic orthostatic hypotension (e.g., in Parkinson’s disease) rather than acute post-spinal hypotension. It has a slow onset and is not suitable for immediate correction of hypotension in LSCS patients.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with seborrheic dermatitis is prescribed a topical corticosteroid creme by his dermatologist in hopes of alleviating the chronic rash and erythema on the cheeks. Which of the following steps is most critical to achieve a therapeutic drug concentration in plasma?

A 61-year-old man is taking over-the-counter pseudoephedrine for cold and flulike symptoms. Over the course of the next few days, he experiences improvement in his rhinitis but should be concerned about the possibility of which of the following problems?

options.label: B
options.text: Constriction of the bronchioles causing increased pulmonary secretions

options.label: D
options.text: Thinning of his salivary glandular secretions

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • However, its α-adrenergic effects can also cause smooth muscle contraction in the bladder neck and prostate, leading to urinary retention, especially in older men or those with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
  • • Mechanism of urinary retention with pseudoephedrine: Stimulation of α 1 receptors in the bladder neck and prostate causes smooth muscle contraction, leading to difficulty in urination. This effect is more pronounced in older men who may already have some degree of prostatic hypertrophy or bladder outlet obstruction. Given that this 61-year-old man is taking pseudoephedrine for cold symptoms, he should be concerned about urinary retention, particularly if he has a history of BPH or difficulty urinating.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: (B) Constriction of the bronchioles causing increased pulmonary secretions
  • • Pseudoephedrine has some α-adrenergic activity, which actually leads to bronchodilation rather than bronchoconstriction. It does not increase pulmonary secretions but rather reduces secretions in the nasal mucosa due to its decongestant effects. This option is incorrect because pseudoephedrine does not cause bronchoconstriction or increased pulmonary secretions. (C) Erectile function improvement
  • • Pseudoephedrine is a vasoconstrictor due to its α 1 agonist activity, which can actually impair erectile function rather than improve it. Erection requires vasodilation (mediated by nitric oxide and parasympathetic activity), but pseudoephedrine causes vasoconstriction, potentially worsening erectile dysfunction. Therefore, pseudoephedrine would not improve erectile function but could instead worsen it. (D) Thinning of his salivary glandular secretions
  • • While pseudoephedrine reduces nasal secretions, it does so by vasoconstriction of nasal blood vessels rather than by directly affecting salivary glands. Anticholinergic drugs (e.g., atropine) are more likely to cause dry mouth and reduced salivary secretions, whereas pseudoephedrine does not significantly affect saliva production.

questions.text: Researchers interested in studying a certain cytochrome P450 enzyme wish to isolate the enzyme of interest from the many other proteins in the cells. One of their initial steps is to lyse the cells and isolate the organelle which carries the enzyme they want to study. Which organelle will they isolate to find CYP enzymes?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Function of CYP enzymes in the SER: They participate in phase I metabolism of drugs by oxidation, reduction, and hydrolysis, making compounds more polar for further metabolism or excretion. They play a crucial role in the synthesis of steroid hormones, bile acids, and cholesterol metabolism. The liver contains a high concentration of SER, making it the main site of CYP enzyme activity. Since the researchers are looking to isolate a cytochrome P450 enzyme, they should isolate the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER), where the majority of CYP enzymes are found.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: (A) Golgi apparatus
  • • The Golgi apparatus is responsible for protein modification, packaging, and transport, but it does not house cytochrome P450 enzymes. It is primarily involved in glycosylation and protein sorting, not in drug metabolism or detoxification. Therefore, this option is incorrect. (C) Mitochondria
  • • Some CYP enzymes (e.g., CYP11A1, CYP11B1, CYP11B2) are found in mitochondria, particularly in steroidogenic tissues (e.g., adrenal glands, testes, and ovaries), where they help in steroid hormone biosynthesis. However, the majority of CYP enzymes, especially those involved in drug metabolism (e.g., CYP3A4, CYP2D6), are located in the SER, not mitochondria. Since the question does not specify steroid metabolism, this option is not the best choice. (D) Peroxisomes
  • • Peroxisomes are involved in β-oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids, hydrogen peroxide metabolism, and lipid metabolism, but they do not contain cytochrome P450 enzymes in significant amounts. CYP enzymes are not primarily located in peroxisomes, making this an incorrect answer.

questions.text: On your emergency duty a concerned mother brought her 4 year old son. She tells you that her son ate a handful of her amitriptyline (a weak acid). At emergency department the child is given bicarbonate (in addition to other measures). What is the most likely explanation for bicarbonate administration in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Bicarbonate should not have been given; a weak acid such as ammonium chloride should have been given instead

options.label: B
options.text: Bicarbonate traps amitriptyline in the blood to keep it from reaching its active site

options.label: C
options.text: Ion trapping the amitriptyline in the urine to hasten elimination is accomplished by giving bicarbonate

options.label: D
options.text: Weak acids such as amitriptyline are chemically inactivated by bicarbonate

questions.correct_answer: C. Ion trapping the amitriptyline in the urine to hasten elimination is accomplished by giving bicarbonate
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Mechanism of ion trapping: Amitriptyline exists in two forms: protonated (charged, BH*) and unprotonated (uncharged, B). In an alkaline environment (high pH, caused by bicarbonate administration), amitriptyline remains in its uncharged form in the blood, which reduces its toxic effects on cardiac sodium channels. In the renal tubules, the alkaline pH converts the drug into its ionized (BH*) form, trapping it in the urine and preventing reabsorption into the bloodstream. This enhances renal clearance and promotes faster elimination of amitriptyline, helping to mitigate toxicity. Thus, administering bicarbonate helps in the elimination of amitriptyline via urinary ion trapping, making option (C) the correct answer.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: (A) Bicarbonate should not have been given; a weak acid such as ammonium chloride should have been given instead
  • • This statement is incorrect because amitriptyline is a weak base, not a weak acid. Ammonium chloride would acidify the urine, which would actually increase reabsorption of amitriptyline, worsening the toxicity. Instead, alkalizing the urine with bicarbonate enhances drug elimination, making this choice incorrect. (B) Bicarbonate traps amitriptyline in the blood to keep it from reaching its active site
  • • Sodium bicarbonate does not trap the drug in the blood; rather, it enhances drug elimination by ion trapping in the urine. Additionally, bicarbonate reduces cardiotoxicity by stabilizing cardiac sodium channels, but it does not "trap" the drug in circulation. This explanation does not correctly describe the mechanism, making it incorrect. (D) Weak acids such as amitriptyline are chemically inactivated by bicarbonate
  • • Amitriptyline is not a weak acid; it is a weak base. Bicarbonate does not chemically inactivate amitriptyline but rather changes its ionization state to facilitate renal elimination.

questions.text: A 21-year-old pregnant female asks her doctor what she can do about her acne. questions.text: A 78-year-old woman with vaginal vault stenosis and urinary burning is prescribed topical estrogen, which is applied to the anterior vaginal wall every other day. Physical examination reveals a mild cystocele. Which of the following statements is correct about this agent?

A 62-year-old man is recovering in the hospital following a heart attack. He is started on clopidogrel. The initial dose, also known as the loading dose, is higher than his normal daily dose, also known as the maintenance dose. Which of the following represents the calculation for a maintenance dose?

options.label: B
options.text: = amount of drug in body/drug plasma concentration

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Incorrect Answers: (A) = 0.7 × Vd / t1/2 Incorrect, because this formula is used to calculate the elimination rate constant (k), not the maintenance dose. The correct relationship is: K=0.7/(t1/2) This helps determine drug elimination over time, but it does not directly determine the maintenance dose. (B) = Amount of drug in body / Drug plasma concentration Incorrect, because this formula calculates the volume of distribution (Vd), not the maintenance dose. The formula for Vd is: Vd=Amount of drug in body/(Plasma concentration (CP)) This helps determine drug distribution, but it does not predict the required dose. (D) = Cp × Vd / F Incorrect, because this is the formula for the loading dose, not the maintenance dose. The loading dose is used to rapidly achieve a therapeutic plasma concentration, whereas the maintenance dose ensures steady-state levels.

questions.text: A researcher pharmacologist at AIIMS is interested in creating an anticholinergic agent that would be useful in patients with irritative bladder symptoms would be interested in targeting which of the following receptors?

You are part a research group which is evaluating the potencies of the a-adrenergic agonists at different receptor sites. Which of the following a-adrenergic agonists would be expected to have the strongest potency at the a-receptor?

A 34-year-old man presents to the hospital with complaints of 2-week history of nasal stuffiness, cough, and sinus pain. He is prescribed with phenylephrine. He must be aware of which of the following potential adverse effects?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Mechanism of Hypertension: Phenylephrine stimulates α 1 receptors on vascular smooth muscle, leading to peripheral vasoconstriction. This increases systemic vascular resistance (SVR), which can raise blood pressure. The increase in blood pressure may trigger a reflex bradycardia as a compensatory response. This effect is more pronounced in elderly patients or those with preexisting hypertension. Because hypertension is a well-known adverse effect of phenylephrine, (D) is the correct answer.
  • • Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: (A) Constipation
  • • Phenylephrine does not have significant effects on the gastrointestinal (GI) system. Constipation is more commonly seen with opioids or drugs with anticholinergic effects (e.g., atropine). Since phenylephrine does not act on muscarinic receptors, constipation is not a typical side effect. (B) Diarrhea
  • • Phenylephrine primarily acts on blood vessels, not on the intestinal smooth muscle. Diarrhea is more commonly associated with drugs that increase GI motility, such as cholinergic agonists or certain antibiotics. Since phenylephrine causes vasoconstriction and not GI stimulation, it is unlikely to cause diarrhea. (C) Epistaxis
  • • Phenylephrine is used as a nasal decongestant due to its vasoconstrictive properties, which help reduce nasal swelling. While excessive use of nasal sprays containing phenylephrine may lead to rebound congestion (rhinitis medicamentosa), it does not directly cause nosebleeds (epistaxis). Epistaxis is more commonly linked to nasal dryness, trauma, or excessive anticoagulation, rather than phenylephrine use.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man has been diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease, the physician starts him on a course of bromocriptine in hope of improving his significant symptoms of cogwheel rigidity and bradykinesia. What is the most likely explanation for these findings?

What else is bupropion commonly used for?

A 59-year-old man presents to the medicine OPD with a shuffling gait, cogwheel rigidity, and a resting tremor. His physician prescribes levodopa and his symptoms greatly improve, supporting a diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease. How does levodopa help this patient’s symptoms?

He was found in the store room with an opened spray bottle of insecticide nearby. He has lost consciousness. His heart rate is 45 beats/minute, and his blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. He is sweating and salivating profusely. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

A 20-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department by the hostel warden after being found by his roommate to have snorted cocaine several times in the past few days, the last time being 10 h previously. He was given a drug that sedated him, and he fell asleep. The drug that was used to counter this patient’s apparent cocaine withdrawal was very likely which of the following?

A 51-year-old man presents to hospital with long-standing schizophrenia is hospitalized for a symptom exacerbation. The psychiatrist places him on a second-generation antipsychotic agent. Characteristics of this agent include which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Considered to be typical antipsychotic agents

options.label: B
options.text: Have fewer extrapyramidal symptoms than first generation agents

options.label: C
options.text: Low risk of development of diabetes mellitus

options.label: D
options.text: Low risk of development of hypercholesterolemia

questions.correct_answer: B. Have fewer extrapyramidal symptoms than first generation agents
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (C) Low risk of development of diabetes mellitus: This statement is incorrect because many SGAs, particularly clozapine and olanzapine, have a high risk of metabolic side effects, including weight gain, insulin resistance, and diabetes mellitus. These effects are due to serotonin (5-HT 1 A) and histamine receptor blockade, which increase appetite and metabolic dysfunction.
  • • (D) Low risk of development of hypercholesterolemia: This is also incorrect, as SGAs, especially clozapine, olanzapine, and quetiapine, are associated with dyslipidemia and hypercholesterolemia. This metabolic dysfunction is linked to their effects on serotonin (5-HT 1 A) and histamine receptors, leading to weight gain and increased triglyceride levels. Aripiprazole and ziprasidone have lower metabolic risks, but overall, SGAs are more likely to cause hypercholesterolemia than FGAs.

questions.text: A 39 -year-old man employed in banking job is suffering with depression, he has been in and out of the psychiatric unit because of noncompliance with medications, he decides to take intranasal Cocaine on a regular basis. He notes that he feels Better and thinks that this helps his depression. Through which of the following mediators does this Effect likely occur?

A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department complaining of crushing chest pain radiating to his left arm. He is admitted, stabilized, and treated for an acute myocardial infarction. Later, he developed ventricular tachycardia and is treated with an antiarrhythmic. After a week of antiarrhythmic treatment, he began having difficulty breathing. A chest X-ray reveals pulmonary fibrosis. Which antiarrhythmic was he taking?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (C) Lidocaine: Lidocaine is a Class IB antiarrhythmic used primarily for acute ventricular arrhythmias, especially in the setting of myocardial infarction. It works by blocking sodium channels, decreasing the action potential duration in ischemic cardiac tissue. Although it has potential side effects like CNS toxicity (confusion, seizures, tremors) and cardiovascular depression, it does not cause pulmonary fibrosis.
  • • (D) Procainamide: Procainamide is a Class IA antiarrhythmic that blocks sodium channels, slowing conduction velocity and prolonging the action potential. It is associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE), which can present with fever, joint pain, and a positive anti-histone antibody test, but not pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man undergoes open-heart surgery for a triple coronary artery bypass graft. His surgery goes smoothly, but the next day he develops chest palpitations. Metoprolol is started to keep his supraventricular tachycardia from interfering with ventricular rhythm. Under which Singh–Vaughan Williams class of antiarrhythmics does metoprolol fall?

A 62-year-old man has developed worsening hypertension despite therapy. His physician wants to prescribe an additional medication that will dilate his blood vessels to help lower his blood pressure. Which Of the following is a calcium channel blocker that works primarily on vascular smooth muscle?

A 67-year-old chronic smoker with COPD and chronic heart failure presents to his primary care physician for follow-up. The patient takes multiple medications for these problems. Which of the following strategies may prove to have additional benefit in the treatment of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Exercise program involving alternating running and walking on a daily basis

options.label: B
options.text: Increase in dietary intake of sodium to 2,000 mg/d

options.label: C
options.text: Stopping use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents

options.label: D
options.text: Use of b-blockers at high doses

questions.correct_answer: C. Stopping use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman with a history of cardiac arrhythmias presents to her primary care physician for follow-up. Her current medications include amiodarone. She complains of a 4-week history of diarrhea, sweats, and muscle weakness. Her skin is normal. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?

A 68 -year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he passed out at home. Electrocardiography reveals an AV nodal–based arrhythmia. What drug would be most effective at interrupting the AV transmission and breaking the arrhythmic cycle at the AV node?

A 78-year-old man with dyspnea is brought to the emergency department for evaluation. Physical examination reveals jugular venous distension and bilateral rales in both lung fields. Chest X-ray reveals pulmonary congestion consistent with fluid overload. What is the best treatment for this patient?

A 57-year-old homeless man with no health insurance has a history of hypertension. He usually takes an antihypertensive agent but has not been able to obtain the medication. He stopped taking the medication yesterday and now is found collapsed in front of a shopping mall. Rescue squad arrives on the scene, and the patient’s blood pressure is 190/110 mm Hg. Which one of the following antihypertensive drugs can precipitate a hypertensive crisis following abrupt cessation of therapy?

A 47-year-old woman with Type-2 diabetes presents to the nephrology clinic for follow-up. She has been doing well other than an increase in her blood sugars lately. She was started on a new medication recently, but she cannot remember the name. All she knows was it affected her kidneys. What is the most likely medication that she started taking?

A 45-year-old man with a family history of hyperlipidemia and heart disease comes to the ER diaphoretic with chest pain radiating to his left arm. An ECG shows ST segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. The doctor administers alteplase intravenously. How does alteplase work?

A 54-year-old woman with severe essential hypertension refractory to treatment switched to a new antihypertensive drug 1 month ago. Her blood pressure is currently well controlled. She now comes complaining of excessive hair growth. What is this drug’s mechanism of action?

A 60-year-old man presents to the hospital complaining of difficulty urinating. Digital rectal exam reveals an enlarged prostate. The patient is started on a trial of terazosin, after which his symptoms improve dramatically. Which of the following side effects is he most likely to experience?

A 61-year-old woman who is a long-term smoker presents to the emergency department with dyspnea and feeling faint. Physical examination reveals bilateral jugular venous distension and significant peripheral edema of both legs up to the knees. Treatment of this condition will be unaffected by which of the following classes of medications?

A 73-year-old man with long-standing heart failure managed with digoxin and a b-blocker suddenly collapses in a while walking in a garden. Attempts to revive him are unsuccessful. Autopsy is performed. Which of the following changes in his heart would be expected to be noted?

A 60-year-old woman suffers an anterior wall myocardial infarction. She recovers well initially but soon develops left heart failure. Her physician prescribes multiple medications to treat different aspects of heart failure, including isosorbide dinitrate. What is the mechanism of action of this agent?

options.label: A
options.text: Blocks the activity of angiotensin II at its receptor

questions.text: A 48-year-old man who has been diagnosed with glaucoma visits a new ophthalmologist for second opinion who prescribes latanoprost for his glaucoma that is refractory to medical treatments. The physician must warn the patient about which of the following possible adverse effects of this medication?

A 55-year-old man presents to the OPD for followup visit, he has congestive heart failure and has been taking a loop diuretic to reduce peripheral edema. His labs reveal a serum potassium of 3.1 mEq/L, so a potassium-sparing diuretic, triamterene, is added to his regimen. Which of the following is the site of action of this agent

options.label: A
options.text: Ascending limb of loop of Henle

options.label: C
options.text: Descending limb of loop of Henle

questions.text: A 42-year-old traveller is on a road trip in south america when he develops diarrhea. He has to give a presentation in a few hours and needs rapid relief. He takes an antidiarrheal preparation containing loperamide. Which of the following is a property of loperamide that makes it useful in treating diarrhea?
questions.correct_answer: D. Inhibitor of myenteric plexus activity

questions.text: A 59-year-old man with history of long-standing hypertension presents to the hospital for follow-up. He is managed with spironolactone. Physical examination reveals bilateral gynecomastia. He states that he has recently underwent an endoscopy, which revealed gastric ulcers. What is the most likely explanation for these findings?

A 40-year-old daily wage labourer with gastroesophageal reflux takes over-the-counter cimetidine from local pharmacy shop. He does not go to see a physician. This patient must be aware of which of the following side effects of this medication?

A 27-year-old man complains of occasional heartburn. His physician makes a few suggestions of diet and lifestyle changes he could make as well as some medications he can take for symptom management. The patient decides to try a magnesium hydroxide (MgOH) preparation. Which of the following is a side effect of MgOH that the physician should warn him about?

A 25-year-old newly married man with complaint of mild erectile dysfunction presents to the clinic. He has no other medical problems. He does have an anxiety disorder. Physical examination of the abdomen and genitalia are within normal limits. Which of the following is the best agent for treatment of this patient?

A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaint of recurrent urinary tract infections, she now has three consecutive UTIs in a 4-month period. Each time, the culture and sensitivity reveal resistance to ciprofloxacin. What is the most likely source of resistance?

A 30 -year-old woman from delhi presents to the psychiatrist with worsening alogia as well as harboring the delusion that her ex husband (who now lives in a different state) is spying on her through her computer. Her physician prescribes chlorpromazine. The physician warns her of possible anticholinergic side effects. Which of the following is an anticholinergic effect?

Concerned mother of a 6-year-old boy takes her son to the medical officer at PHC, she complains that her son has developed a cough, stuffy nose, headache, and fever for 2 days. Medical officer prescribes a cough syrup containing guaifenesin. Which of the following effects is likely caused by guaifenesin?

A 40-year-old man has been diagnosed with nonseminomatous germ cell tumor of the testis further examination and investigations reveal bulky lymphadenopathy, patient undergoes orchiectomy followed by multiagent chemotherapy with high-dose methotrexate. His serum creatinine rises from 1.10 mg/dL at baseline to 3.50 mg/dL after 4 weeks of therapy. What is the most likely explanation for this finding?
questions.correct_answer: B. Crystallization in the renal tubules

questions.text: A 40 -year-old actress presents to the dermatologist for treatment to address her wrinkles. She complains that her right eyelid and forehead are “too droopy” and has a persistent head ache since her first Botox treatment 5 days ago. What is the mechanism of action for this treatment?

options.label: C
options.text: Blocks uptake of choline into nerve terminals

questions.correct_answer: D. Prevents release of cholinergic vesicles

questions.text: A 35 -year-old woman with recurrent migraine headaches presents to her physician for evaluation and treatment. Physical examination of the head and neck is unremarkable. Treatment with zolmitriptan has begun. This agent acts on which of the following receptors in the brain?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (A) Acetylcholine Incorrect because acetylcholine (ACh) does not play a major role in migraine treatment. ACh is involved in parasympathetic signaling and neuromuscular transmission. Drugs affecting ACh (e.g., anticholinergics like atropine or cholinesterase inhibitors like donepezil) do not treat migraines.
  • • (C) Dopamine Incorrect because triptans do not primarily act on dopamine receptors. Dopamine plays a role in nausea and vomiting associated with migraines, and dopamine antagonists (e.g., metoclopramide, prochlorperazine) are sometimes used as adjunct therapy for migraines, but triptans act on serotonin, not dopamine.
  • • (D) Epinephrine Incorrect because triptans do not directly affect epinephrine receptors. Epinephrine acts on α and β-adrenergic receptors, influencing heart rate, vasoconstriction, and bronchodilation. Adrenergic agonists (e.g., epinephrine, norepinephrine) are not used for migraine treatment.

questions.text: A 70 -year-old woman presents to the geriatric clinic with complaint of trouble falling asleep at night. Her daughter also mentions that her mother’s mood appears depressed, and also states that she is not eating well. Which of the following medications could best help this patient?
A 35-year-old obese man complains of postprandial, burning chest pain. His physician prescribes pantoprazole. Pantoprazole may impair absorption of which of the following nutrients?

A 57-year-old postmenopausal woman presents to the OPD with complaint of urinary urge incontinence. Medical history is significant for hypertension, which is controlled with losartan. She is not a surgical candidate so pharmacological therapy is chosen to treat her condition, and she begins treatment with solifenacin. Which of the following side effects is most likely to occur in this patient?
An opthalmologist prescribes atropine eye drops to a 40-year-old man who is a businesman, this drug would produce which of the following effects?

A 27-year-old G2P1 woman from rural area at 33 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department of your medical college, she complains of pain and swelling in her right calf. On physical examination, Homans sign is positive. A duplex of the right calf confirms the presence of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). What is the most appropriate treatment for the rest of her pregnancy?
